WRITING.TEXT: I'm biracial too!

Stuff like this happens to thin people too.
It took a while to get a diagnosis for my younger sisters GI condition because everyone just assumed that that her problems were caused by an eating disorder and tried to just stick her in therapy.
We don't blame the doctors because that wasn't a crazy thing for them to think, especially since I struggle with anorexia and it tends to run in families.
I think what really kills a lot of people is the amount of calories that can be consumed in coffee and pop to stay awake during a 12 hour shift.

I'm a nursing major, and we regularly talk about how obesity is such a HUGE problem in nursing.
My freshman year we actually had to do assignments where we used MFP and pedometers and wrote reflections on how we could make healthier choices. As someone struggling with anorexia I was SO scared of being outed during that assignment.

My mom did sooo much research on black hair because she didn't want me to walk around "looking like I had a white mom"
I was born before the internet was really a thing (the mid 90's) so she would just ask random friendly looking black women in the supermarket what to do!

I am personally against abortion, but I vote pro-choice because I understand that we don't live in a world where banning abortion is a realistic goal. As someone from a relatively privileged background, I know that I will never fully understand what can drive a woman to make the decision to terminate a pregnancy. I also understand that sadly, we live in a world where many women may see abortion as their only option as the very same people who push to stop abortion seem to stop caring about the sanctity of life once a baby exits the birth canal. Banning abortion won't do anything but further burden marginalized women; to prevent abortions we need to create a system that better helps women prevent unwanted pregnancies, and provides proper support to those who become pregnant whether they want to keep the child or give it up.

I like full length (ankle length) tights or shorts when I'm working out.
I just don't like the way cropped/capri leggings look with my running shoes, which is weird because I think that they look fine on other people!

I think this post might be referring to "running tights" which are like leggings.
At tights are still awful when you're dancing, unless my teacher is super strict I try to avoid wearing tights to ballet because it is such a pain to peel them off of your sweaty body!
I think that sign language is a great 'fun' language for kids because its only function is communication since Deaf and HoH people read and write in the spoken language of their area.

I usually drive because I'm a bit of a control freak and my boyfriend drives like an old lady.
I grew up in a family where my dad always drove; I don't think I have ever seen my mom drive with my dad as a passenger. While my mom is a completely fine driver and we all trust her, she always lets my dad drive if they are going somewhere together because driving is something that he actively enjoys where she just sees it as a way to get from point 'a' to point 'b'.
I don't think that this comes from women thinking that they 'can't' drive their male partner, I think it is more that male partners tend to have stronger feelings about driving and a lot of women just couldn't care less.

BSN, RN, CEN, CFRN, CTRN, CRNFA,
I'm still a student, so I'm not completely sure what my longterm career goals are yet; right now I really want to work in an ED and do flight nursing, but I could also see myself in an OR or inpatient burn center, especially as I get older.
I'm kind of counting on my accent being so bad that patients will know that I am not even a passable Spanish speaker.
My boyfriend's mom is a doctor and she always talk about how much she respects vets because she couldn't imagine having to know about more than one species!

It's not that white parents discourage other people from engaging with their kids (I've never experienced it anyway), it is that in my experience, Asian parents tend to actively encourage it and will ask a stranger to hold their baby while they get something out of their purse where white parents are more likely to just smile at you if they notice you interacting with their child.

Basic health stuff.
Know how to deal with basic illnesses and injuries and actually have the supplies that you will need.
Know what things you just need to wait out (colds etc.), what you should make a doctors appointment for (cold that has lasted a really long time, green snot and sinus pressure, signs of strep), what warrants taking a trip to urgent care (sprains, inability to keep down fluids after 24 hours with a stomach bug) and when you should to go to the emergency department (medical emergencies)

When my cousin lived in Japan (her husband was stationed there) it blew her mind that random people on the train would offer to hold her baby for her so that she could get her things organized or just to give her a break.
I personally have noticed that Asian parents seem to really like it when strangers engage with their kids in public (smiling and playing peek-a-boo etc.) where more white parents have the attitude that this is THEIR child.
People saying that they "could care less" when they actually mean to say that they "COULDN'T care less"
I'm 19 and in the fall I'll be starting the 2nd year of my BSN program but right now I'm a full time summer camp counselor!

I really like Wen cleansing conditioner, it keeps my hair soft and it smells really nice.
I'm sure I could find another product for cheaper that does the same thing, but my hair is super short so it takes me about a year to finish a big pump bottles of it.

I could honestly go either way; I'm usually the little spoon, but from time to time my boyfriend and I will switch.
We call it "jetpacking" when I'm the big spoon because I'm tiny compared to him.

I like guys who are tall and slim, but still have some muscle tone (so runners, swimmers etc.)
They don't have to be ripped or have abs that I could do laundry on, but I'm not into the "skinnyfat" look (tiny everywhere except for the beer gut).
My current boyfriend is kind of my ideal; he is 6'5'' and a college rower, so he is pretty lean but I never have to worry about him weighing less than me.
I'm still not over My Chemical Romance breaking up, but I'm really excited to see more of Gerard Way's work in comics and cartoons!

I've started using avocado to make tuna and it is probably the best thing ever, especially if you add mustard.
I personally like to eat it in a wrap, if you add some spinach and have some carrots and a banana on the side it makes a super filling lunch that comes in under 500 calories!

I had a guy open with this and then say "and I bet your mom is white, right? Girls with white moms are always the hottest"
The worst part is he was biracial too, how did he not know better?

I think the worst is hearing white people talk about how they need to find an (insert race partner) so they can have mixed babies.
Sometimes I feel like a laberdoodle with the way that people talk about me.

As long as they accept that I will never be vegan and understand that it isn't a viable lifestyle for everyone I'd be fine with it.
I am recovering from a restrictive eating disorder (anorexia) and veganism is just too restrictive for me to maintain a healthy mindset, especially since my diet is already restricted because I have celiac disease.

That is awesome! I have so much respect for people who are able to lose weight while dealing with serious health conditions; while being sick clearly doesn't cause weight gain, I can completely understand why it is so tempting to just do what is easy and pleasurable in the short term (eating too much etc.) when you're feeling crappy and just getting through the day is effort.

I'm biracial (half black, half white) so this is basically my life.
Growing up, I was always told that I was "too white" by the other black kids in my school; I am a shy, soft spoken science geek with an ass so flat that it is basically concave, but, my white friends always thought of me as black because of my skin and hair.
I identify as biracial; though I really don't identify with black culture, I am obviously not white and I have never really seen myself as white.

I feel you on this. I know that it shouldn't but it really bothers me when people just refer to me as black, because it just doesn't feel accurate to me. I am just as white as I am black, and I consider myself to be biracial.

Ugh I wish I could wear a tankini, but they specifically asked us to wear one piece swimsuits so I don't want to push it since I'm a new employee.

Yorkies are actually one of the few small dogs that I would consider getting because they do tend to have personality, and they were bred to work so they can be reasonably active.
Obviously you couldn't take one on a long run but they still feel like "real" dogs to me.

I met several women when I was in treatment who developed eating disorders after being diagnosed with gastrointestinal disorders. Food became scary because they knew that they might feel sick after eating, and not eating felt like a way to control this condition that often made them feel like they weren't in control of their bodies.

WRITING.TITLE: One piece athletic swimsuits?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey ladies! I am got a summer job as a camp counselor, so I need to get a "work appropriate", speedo style swimsuit!
I'm having a bit of trouble because it seems like each part of my body needs a different size; I basically have the body of a 13 year old boy (no hips or butt), but I have big boobs (I wear a 28F or 30E), and a 24 inch waist. I'm also on the tall side (5'8'') and I get a decent amount of height from my torso but I only weigh 120 pounds. As you can see, my body makes no sense.
I'm cool with a suit that just smooshes my boobs down, but I'm concerned about them spilling out of the top or sides of the suit.
As one of my professors (a former ED doc) said "frequent fliers get sick too"

My boyfriend and I broke up when we went away to different colleges because I felt like it was what we were "supposed" to do as high school relationships rarely last. I have always been rational to a fault and despite how much I loved him I convinced myself that I was not mature enough to commit myself to a relationship and "know" what I wanted.
We ended up getting back together after 6 months of being best friends, and we are still really happy together. I don't know if we will be together "forever" but we both realized that we make each other happy and that it is kind of silly to apply population statistics to an individual case.

* Eating 3 meals and 2 snacks
* Getting up before 9 am
* Getting 10,000 steps
* Drinking at least 2 liters of water
* Took morning and night meds
* Didn't lose weight
* Had normal(ish) vitals
I'm home for summer vacation and my job hasn't started yet so I'm home alone all day with no real commitments. Basically I'm just trying to not be a complete sloth and at least half ass my eating disorder recovery.

Nothing, because I'm one of the older generic pills.
Thanks Obama!

I think it helps people to have an arbitrary restriction because it prevents impulsive eating; if you are be gluten free or low carb you CAN'T have a piece of the cake that your coworker brought in, but if you are just counting calories it may be easier to convince yourself that you will "make up for it" later.
That's just my theory.

Fat dogs make me so sad. They don't get to control their food intake, and when they are big they are unable to do the things that make them happiest!
It breaks my heart that some people would rather their pets be uncomfortable and lethargic than healthy and energetic because they are too lazy to meet the needs of a happy dog.
My 78 year old grandmother knows that she isn't active enough to keep her dog happy; so she takes him to doggy daycare so he can run around and play with other dogs because she knows that he would be miserable if he only went on the leisurely, 1/2 walks that she is capable of taking him on.

Do people not understand that gay men are capable of appreciating female beauty? You can find someone attractive without being attracted to them; there are plenty of people who are very much not my "type", but I am able to see why others would find them attractive; my super straight boyfriend can still see that Idris Elba is a good looking man even though he has no desire to get with him.

I am so, so sorry that you have had such a rough time, and I really hope that you are able to accept your diagnosis and get the help that you need, because eating disorders are SERIOUS and you can be suffering at any weight. You ended up in the hospital, and these days they don't admit people unless they really need to be there; if people who have spent the majority of their adult lives studying the human body are telling you that you are sick, it is probably a good idea to listen.
Starvation impairs your cognition; it causes cerebral atrophy (your brain literally shrinks) so between that and the eating disorder you are not able to think clearly or rationally right now, that is just a fact. In order to do the emotional work that you need to heal, you need to normalize your intake so that your brain has the nutrients that it needs to work properly.
I can promise you that there will never be a time when you feel like you are thin or sick enough to justify getting better; you need to take a leap of faith and allow yourself to be taken care of physically before your denial kills you, because it will kill you.
I just want to give you a hug right now
I live in Pennsylvania but I go to Delaware to take advantage of your nonexistent sales tax and slightly less draconian liquor laws.

I also shave, but my armpits are concave, so it is really hard to effectively shave them.

The same thing happened to me!
You go girl! I don't have advice, but eating disorders are the worst and I wish you the best.

I lost over 10 pounds in the 2 weeks after I got my wisdom teeth removed.
It is hard to say how much weight I have lost through out my eating disorder, because I developed anorexia during puberty. I'm about 5'8'' and I've fluctuated between 128 (low end of healthy for me) and 115 (hospital) since I was about 11.

I haven't tried the tops (because boobs) but all of the running shorts and spandex that I have gotten work great.

A lot of things can happen that will push a doctor behind.
You have a kid come in for a normal physical and when you are examining them you hear a heart murmur so you have to get an EKG, educate the family and make a referral to cardiology.
You have a patient coming in for follow up on a chronic disease, and their lab results look kind of funky, so instead of just asking them how things are going and doing a basic exam you have to do a full head to toe and have repeat labs drawn so you can see if this was just a fluke or if they need to be admitted.
And then there are the patients who come in for a cold and as you are leaving the room say "oh, so it burns when I pee and I have this rash on my junk, thats ok right"

Yup! I know that there have been times where my doctor took her time with me and ran late for the person after me, so I'm not too bothered when I have to wait a bit if she is running behind.
She usually runs pretty on time, and whenever there is a wait she is always super apologetic, but I know that once she is in the room with me she will take her time and make sure that she does all that she can to help me.

Wait until they find out that there is no "cure" for cancer, because cancer is a super broad term that covers a whole bunch of diseases that need to be treated in different ways.
What does it even mean to "cure" cancer; we have gotten pretty good at treating a lot of cancers, but they can still come back even after a patient is declared cancer free. We have also made a lot of cancers more survivable; even if we can't completely get rid of the disease, patients are able to live with cancer for a long time and maintain a pretty good quality of life.

I mean even super high amounts of lean mass can ultimately be bad for you; your blood vessels still have to get longer to maintain circulation, and this increase in length causes an increase in blood pressure which puts strain on the heart.
The human body is meant to exist within a certain size range; being really big regardless of the composition of your mass is still a lot of strain on your organs.

I personally did not wait until marriage, but I did wait until I was in a longterm, committed relationship with a guy that I love and I feel like that was the right choice for me. Even if my boyfriend and I don't end up married, I don't think that I will regret sleeping with him.

Now that it always looks good I have so much more confidence and never have to worry that it will "drag down" my look.

Yay, someone else my age with short hair!
I feel like girls our age are so scared to cut their hair; almost everyone I know has shoulder-mid back length hair and they complain about how annoying it is but look at me like I'm crazy when I suggest trying a shorter look.

I'm 19 and this is my hair is short. I've had some variation of the same haircut since I was 16 and I absolutely love it. Cutting off my hair was one of the best things that I ever did for myself and I can't ever see myself going back.
The style varies because I keep it so short I can change it up a lot without really committing, and I'm really lazy so I'll go a long time between cuts and call it a style.

My boyfriend and I broke up when I went away for college because we felt like it was what we were "supposed" to do. We started dating when I was in 10th grade and he was in 11th and had always been taught that high school relationships don't last.
We got back together after about 6 months "apart" (we still talked everyday and neither of us really did anything with another person) and we are still really happy together.

For me it was just exposure. I have to get blood drawn almost every week, so I'm fine with it now, but shots still freak me out because I don't get them often so I psych myself out.
With shots, I do best when they just stick it in without warning, if the person administering it counts down or whatever I have time to start freaking out and tense up, which will make it hurt worse.
If you are a fainter it could be a physiological response since needle sticks are a super common trigger for vasovagal syncope. Its basically just your body overreacting to a stimulus. When you are stressed your sympathetic nervous system will increase your heart rate and constrict your blood vessels which will lead to an increase in blood pressure. Your body wants to regulate itself, so the parasympathetic nervous system will be activated in response to your elevated blood pressure, and it will dilate your blood vessels and slow your heart rate to get your BP down. In vasovagal syncope, your parasympathetic nervous system does too good of a job and your BP gets too low, so you pass out. Fainting actually serves a purpose, as it gets you to a horizontal position, so blood doesn't have to fight gravity to get to your brain.

Thanks for the suggestion!
My issue isn't so much taking the exam as it is coping with my anxiety before and after. I have nightmares for weeks before big tests and have trouble studying because I'll get paralyzed with the fear that nothing I do will be enough. I'm the girl puking in the bathroom before a test and tearfully calling her mom afterwards to ask if she will still love me if I fail.

I would have no problem with my partner owning guns for hunting or target shooting as long as they are stored properly.
I would also be ok with them having a small gun at home to scare off wildlife if we lived in a place where we could end up with a gator or bear in our yard.

Well, before we started dating I thought that I was a lesbian because I wasn't attracted to any of the boys in my middle school. Turns out I'm bisexual and can be attracted to men, once they have gone through puberty.
My boyfriend and I started dating when I was in 10th grade and he was in 11th, and we are still incredibly happy together after close to 4 years.
We have survived him going away to college 4 hours away from home, me having a really severe relapse into my eating disorder, 7 fucking proms, me going to college 10 hours away from home (4 or 5 hours away from his college) and brief "breakup" (we still talked every single day) when I started college because we are too gosh darned rational and felt like we had to because "high school relationships don't last".
Our relationship is disgustingly healthy, which is impressive since we neither of our parents are the best examples (his parents had an ugly divorce, mine are together but don't particularly like each other). My face still lights up whenever I talk about him, and I truly do think that he is the love of my life. I don't know what is going to happen in the future, maybe we'll be together forever, maybe we won't but I feel so lucky to have been able to spend my formative years with such a kind, caring and intelligent man.
We call them "Cafeteria Catholics"!
I like you.

Not very often. I'm 19 and I grew up around Philadelphia.
I'm not bothered by swearing, I come from a pretty potty mouthed family but I personally try to watch my language because I work with kids; its just easier for me to keep it PG all of the time.
I also try to avoid swearing because it can make you sound really immature, as a really young looking person I don't need to give people another reason to mistake me for a 7th grader.

My first year went really, really well! I struggled a fair amount: I developed really severe testing anxiety and ended up in the hospital because of my eating disorder, but I was able to handle these things like an adult and I was still academically successful in my challenging program.
I think that being 10 hours away from home was really good for me, I overcame a lot of my fears because I had no choice but to do things that made me uncomfortable. School also gave me motivation to continue recovering from my eating disorder. I had a lot of support; I have a therapist at school and had almost weekly doctor appointments to monitor my weight but I stayed compliant because I was so happy at school that I was willing to do anything to make sure I could stay.
I really surprised myself with how outgoing I was able to be; I tend to be very shy and didn't really have friends in high school so I was worried that I would end up lonely. I went to football games and frat parties and flirted with boys- all things I never thought that I would do.
If I could have done anything differently, I would have worked on my study skills more in high school! I never had to study to do well in high school, even in my AP classes my idea of "studying" was skimming my notes for 45 minutes the night before an exam. I did well, but I think this year would have been a lot easier if I didn't have to spend time learning how to study.

He doesn't floss everyday. He does most days but I can't understand how he can tolerate skipping at all.
Like, you see how much stuff comes out from between your teeth when you floss, how are you ok with just leaving it in there to fester 1 or 2 times a week?

As long as your weight is stable and all of your other health indicators are in a good range, most doctors don't really worry if a person is carrying a few (as in 15 or fewer) extra pounds, especially as they get older.

I'm Catholic. I don't think that I was ever taught anything about masturbating in church or CCD (it is possible that I was and the metaphors they used just went over my head as I was a really literal kid).
I don't think that masturbation is inherently sinful, but it has the potential to be sinful, like most other activities.
I do masturbate with some regularity (probably a few times a month) and I generally feel the urge pretty easy to resist. I don't have a high sex drive so while masturbating is enjoyable when I do it I could just as easily abstain completely.
